   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:13.9/31.1/1.2, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:50/6/0.05, ALT / AST:[**9-12**], Alk Phos / T Bili:56/0.4, Amylase
   / Lipase:52/10, Differential-Neuts:90.7 %, Band:0.0 %, Lymph:3.7 %,
   Mono:5.4 %, Eos:0.0 %, Lactic Acid:0.6 mmol/L, Albumin:2.0 g/dL,
   LDH:208 IU/L, Ca++:6.8 mg/dL, Mg++:1.4 mg/dL, PO4:2.4 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   66 yo female with a significant history of obstructive lung disease and
   now has evolved respiratory failure in the setting of what is likely
   aspiration event and mucus plugging. She has had ICU course complicated
   by significant hypotension and PTX at the time of CVL placement.  She
   does have significant changes in her ECG in the setting of normal
   enzymes but does represent change from previous.
    1)Respiratory Failure-Likely aspiration and mucus plugging in the
   setting of severe background lung disease.  This is supported by
   minimal resistance on the ventilator and capacity to tolerate RR=20
   with minimal autopeep.
   -AC support, weaned fi02 last night in the setting of elevated PaO2
   -NPO and OGT to suction to prevent furthur aspiration
   -Goal PCO2=55-60
   -consider PE as etiology for initial hypoxia interesting given deep
   t-wave inversion but clinical scenario is with significant alternative
   explanations, low CVP and primary bronchospasm noted with event.
   -Will start coverage with Vanco/Zosyn
   -Sputum culture to be sent
   -Will check CK/Troponin but so far negative
   2)Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease with Acute Exacerbation-
   -Continue with bronchodilators
 xopenex and ipratropium, suspect that
   patient should not get albuterol and xopenex at the same time
   -No systemic steroids at this time as bronchospasm does seem to be
   improved.
    3)Shock-Septic or Hypovolemic
   -CVP is reasonably low
   -She may have a component of neuropathic contribution but is not
   hypotensive at baseline
   -No evidence of acute MI to suggest cardiogenic shock and CVP is low
   -PE raised as possibility but it does appear to be a vasodilatory shock
   state and less likely obstructive, will get echo this morning to rule
   out right heart strain
   -This may be SIRS in the setting of aspiration pneumonitis
   -move CVP to goal of 12
   -Continue with Levophed and hope to wean with continued volume
   repletion
   -Will work to wean sedation as possible as may be a contributor to
   hypotension
   -ECHO to f/u if quick response is not seen
   4)Atrial Fibrillation-
   -Paitent with A-fib suggested on ECG and telemetry
   -Will consider cardioversion if persistent hypotension seen and not
   able to be tolerated with pressor support
   -ECG changes may well be demand ischemia and will follow enzymes which
   are negative to date.
   -Will continue Digoxin as patient transiently in sinus rhythm
    5)Pneumonthorax-
   -Chest tube in place, maintain suction
   -Currently with small leak noted
   -Minimal drainage
   - continued chest tube while on postive pressure ventilation and until
   air appears to have drained from chest tube completely
   EKG changes:  Diffuse T wave inversions in inferior and anterior
   distribution.  Most likely related to demand ischemia in RCA and LAD
   territory.  Pulmonary embolism considered but would be less likely to
   cause strain in both arterial territories.  Diffuse changes also less
   consistent with myocardial infarction.
   - repeat EKG after improvement in hemodynamics
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - echocardiogram today
   .
   Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  Currently with dark black material
   in NGT which is hemoccult negative.  Per hospitalist on floor, this
   likely is related to bannana flakes in patient's tube feeds.  On floor
   patient continued to have severe nausea and vomiting in relation to any
   PO intake.  Gastric emptying study showed 0% emptying at 4 hours.  Also
   stool occult positive.
   - serial hematocrits given concern initially for GI bleeding
   - active type and cross
   - currently intubated, sedated
   - nutrition consult
   - currently with significant black material being suctioned from
   stomach so unlikely will be able to administer PO medications or tube
   feeds until this has improved
   - currently holding j-tube feeds
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   .
   Chronic Abdominal Pain:  Likely related to gastritis.  Also concern
   that G-J tube may have possible leak.  Being followed by GI consult
   service.  She has had many upper endoscopies and suboptimal
   colonoscopies.  Plans is currently for optomizing her nutritional
   status and ultimately rehab.
   - currently on fentanyl for sedation, will have to reassess pain
   regimen when sedation decreased
   - follow gastroenterology recommendations
   .
   Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Previously in this admission with mild iron
   deficiency and chronic disease.  Baseline hematocrit 30-35.  Currently
   26 in the setting of significant IV fluid administration.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   - active type and screen
   .
   COPD: Severe emphysema on imaging.  Likely contributing to her
   respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers of xopenex and ipratropium
   - titrate oxygen for sats > 90%
   .
   Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty.
   - continue fentanyl for sedation
   - reassess pain regimen once medications weaned
   .
   FEN: NPO, IVF for above parameters, nutrition consult, replete
   electrolytes
   .
   Prophylaxis: SC  heparin
   .
   Code: Full code
   .
   Communication: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 849**] Daughter [**Known firstname 341**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 850**].  Alternate is son
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 851**].
   .
   Disposition: ICU care for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a complicated medical history, including esophagectomy, COPD, and atrial arrhythmia. She was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress, recurrent coffee ground emesis, and melena, and was found to have a pneumothorax and subclavian line placement with pneumothorax. She has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. Her laboratory results show significant changes, including anemia, hypocalcemia, and abnormal liver enzymes.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to aspiration and mucus plugging, which is exacerbated by her severe background lung disease. She requires continued ventilatory support and may require tracheostomy.
2. Shock: The patient's hypotension may be due to septic or hypovolemic shock, and she requires continued vasopressor support. An echocardiogram is planned to rule out right heart strain.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely due to demand ischemia, and she may require cardioversion if persistent hypotension is seen.
4. Pneumothorax: The patient's pneumothorax requires continued chest tube drainage and suction.
5. Gastroparesis: The patient's gastroparesis is likely due to her esophagectomy and may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Chronic Abdominal Pain: The patient's chronic abdominal pain is likely related to gastritis and may require further evaluation and treatment.
7. Chronic Blood Loss Anemia: The patient's chronic blood loss anemia is likely due to her esophagectomy and may require further evaluation and treatment.
8. COPD: The patient's COPD is severe and may require continued nebulizer therapy and oxygen supplementation.
9. Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures: The patient's chronic back pain and compression fractures may require further evaluation and treatment.

Plan:

1. Continue ventilatory support and monitor for signs of respiratory failure.
2. Continue vasopressor support and monitor for signs of shock.
3. Consider cardioversion for atrial fibrillation.
4. Continue chest tube drainage and suction for pneumothorax.
5. Evaluate and treat gastroparesis.
6. Evaluate and treat chronic abdominal pain.
7. Monitor and treat chronic blood loss anemia.
8. Continue nebulizer therapy and oxygen supplementation for COPD.
9. Evaluate and treat chronic back pain and compression fractures.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 yo female with a significant history of obstructive lung disease and
   now has evolved respiratory failure in the setting of what is likely
   aspiration event and mucus plugging. She has had ICU course complicated
   by significant hypotension and PTX at the time of CVL placement.  She
   does have significant changes in her ECG in the setting of normal
   enzymes but does represent change from previous.
    1)Respiratory Failure-Likely aspiration and mucus plugging in the
   setting of severe background lung disease.  This is supported by
   minimal resistance on the ventilator and capacity to tolerate RR=20
   with minimal autopeep.
   -AC support, weaned fi02 last night in the setting of elevated PaO2
   -NPO and OGT to suction to prevent furthur aspiration
   -Goal PCO2=55-60
   -will get CTA chest this morning to evaluate for possible PE/aspiration
   event
   -cont  Vanco/Zosyn
   -Sputum culture ordered, not yet sent
   - troponin 0.05, CKs are flat, do not suspect myocardial infarction as
   etiology of event
   2)Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease with Acute Exacerbation-
   -Continue with bronchodilators
 xopenex and ipratropium, suspect that
   patient should not get albuterol and xopenex at the same time
   -No systemic steroids at this time as bronchospasm does seem to be
   improved.
    3)Shock-Septic or Hypovolemic
   -CVP is reasonably low, now improved
   - place a-line this morning
   - check cortisol, consider stress dose steroids
   -She may have a component of neuropathic contribution but is not
   hypotensive at baseline
   -No evidence of acute MI to suggest cardiogenic shock and CVP was low
   initially
   -PE raised as possibility but it does appear to be a vasodilatory shock
   state and less likely obstructive, will get echo this morning to rule
   out right heart strain in addition to CTA
   -This may be SIRS in the setting of aspiration pneumonitis
   -move CVP to goal of 12
   -Continue with Levophed and hope to wean with continued volume
   repletion
   -Will work to wean sedation as possible as may be a contributor to
   hypotension,
   4)Atrial Fibrillation-
   -Paitent with A-fib suggested on ECG and telemetry
    -ECG changes may well be demand ischemia and will follow enzymes which
   are negative to date.
   -Will continue Digoxin as patient transiently in sinus rhythm
    5)Pneumonthorax-
   -Chest tube in place, maintain suction
   -Currently with small leak noted
   -Minimal drainage
   - continued chest tube while on postive pressure ventilation and until
   air appears to have drained from chest tube completely
   EKG changes:  Diffuse T wave inversions in inferior and anterior
   distribution.  Most likely related to demand ischemia in RCA and LAD
   territory.  Pulmonary embolism considered but would be less likely to
   cause strain in both arterial territories.  Diffuse changes also less
   consistent with myocardial infarction.
   - repeat EKG after improvement in hemodynamics
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - echocardiogram today
   .
   Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  Currently with dark black material
   in NGT which is hemoccult negative.  Per hospitalist on floor, this
   likely is related to bannana flakes in patient's tube feeds.  On floor
   patient continued to have severe nausea and vomiting in relation to any
   PO intake.  Gastric emptying study showed 0% emptying at 4 hours.  Also
   stool occult positive.
   - serial hematocrits given concern initially for GI bleeding
   - consider gi consult to assess
   - IV reglan
   - active type and cross
   - currently intubated, sedated, NPO
   - nutrition consult
   - currently with significant black material being suctioned from
   stomach so unlikely will be able to administer PO medications or tube
   feeds until this has improved
   - currently holding j-tube feeds
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   .
   Chronic Abdominal Pain:  Likely related to gastritis.  Also concern
   that G-J tube may have possible leak.  Being followed by GI consult
   service.  She has had many upper endoscopies and suboptimal
   colonoscopies.  Plans is currently for optomizing her nutritional
   status and ultimately rehab.
   - currently on fentanyl for sedation, will have to reassess pain
   regimen when sedation decreased
   - reconsult gi?
   - consider other agents such as low dose haldol to improve pain/psych
   issues and wean off a bit of sedation
   - also will calculate total narcotics previously used to assess how
   well we are treating her pain
   .
   Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Previously in this admission with mild iron
   deficiency and chronic disease.  Baseline hematocrit 30-35.  Currently
   26 in the setting of significant IV fluid administration.
   - serial hematocrits
   - guaic positive which is chronic, crit is stable
   - transfusion goal < 21
   - active type and screen
   .
   COPD: Severe emphysema on imaging.  Likely contributing to her
   respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers of xopenex and ipratropium
   - titrate oxygen for sats > 90%
   .
   Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty.
   - continue fentanyl for sedation
   - reassess pain regimen once medications weaned
   .
   FEN: NPO, IVF for above parameters, nutrition consult, replete

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old female with a complicated medical history, including esophagectomy, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial arrhythmia, and a history of gastrointestinal bleeding. She was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute respiratory distress, recurrent coffee ground emesis, and melena.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 350 mL, respiratory rate of 20, and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. Her oxygen saturation is 97% on 50% FiO2.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient is receiving norepinephrine for hypotension, with a blood pressure of 121/57 mmHg. Her cardiac enzymes are normal, and there is no evidence of acute myocardial infarction.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has dark black material in her nasogastric tube, which is hemoccult negative. She has a history of gastritis and is currently receiving IV reglan.
* Hematological status: The patient's hemoglobin is 7.8 g/dL, and her hematocrit is 26.2%. She is receiving blood products, and her platelet count is 333 K/uL.
* Renal status: The patient's creatinine is 0.4 mg/dL, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 25 mEq/L.
* Neurological status: The patient is sedated and unable to assess her neurological status.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Aspiration pneumonitis: The patient's history of COPD and recent aspiration event increase her risk of developing aspiration pneumonitis.
* Pneumothorax: The patient has a chest tube in place to manage her pneumothorax, but there is a risk of recurrence.
* Shock: The patient's hypotension may be due to septic shock, hypovolemic shock, or vasodilatory shock. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and recent coffee ground emesis increase her risk of bleeding.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if she does not improve with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
* Cardiac arrhythmia: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen if her underlying cardiac condition is not addressed.

The plan for the patient's care includes:

* Continuing mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to manage her respiratory failure
* Managing her hypotension with norepinephrine and volume repletion
* Monitoring her gastrointestinal status and managing her nausea and vomiting with IV reglan
* Reassessing her pain regimen and adjusting as needed
* Continuing her anticoagulation therapy with heparin
* Monitoring her hemoglobin and hematocrit levels and transfusing as needed
* Reassessing her cardiac enzymes and echocardiogram to rule out myocardial infarction
* Continuing her nutrition and glycemic control management
* Monitoring her for signs of sepsis and adjusting her antibiotic therapy as needed.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 yo female with a significant history of obstructive lung disease and
   now has evolved respiratory failure in the setting of what is likely
   aspiration event and mucus plugging. She has had ICU course complicated
   by significant hypotension and PTX at the time of CVL placement.  She
   does have significant changes in her ECG in the setting of normal
   enzymes but does represent change from previous.
    1)Respiratory Failure-Likely aspiration and mucus plugging in the
   setting of severe background lung disease.  This is supported by
   minimal resistance on the ventilator and capacity to tolerate RR=20
   with minimal autopeep.
   -AC support, weaned fi02 last night in the setting of elevated PaO2
   -NPO and OGT to suction to prevent furthur aspiration
   -Goal PCO2=55-60
   -consider PE as etiology for initial hypoxia interesting given deep
   t-wave inversion but clinical scenario is with significant alternative
   explanations, low CVP and primary bronchospasm noted with event.
   -Will start coverage with Vanco/Zosyn
   -Sputum culture to be sent
   -Will check CK/Troponin but so far negative
   2)Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease with Acute Exacerbation-
   -Continue with bronchodilators
 xopenex and ipratropium, suspect that
   patient should not get albuterol and xopenex at the same time
   -No systemic steroids at this time as bronchospasm does seem to be
   improved.
    3)Shock-Septic or Hypovolemic
   -CVP is reasonably low
   -She may have a component of neuropathic contribution but is not
   hypotensive at baseline
   -No evidence of acute MI to suggest cardiogenic shock and CVP is low
   -PE raised as possibility but it does appear to be a vasodilatory shock
   state and less likely obstructive, will get echo this morning to rule
   out right heart strain
   -This may be SIRS in the setting of aspiration pneumonitis
   -move CVP to goal of 12
   -Continue with Levophed and hope to wean with continued volume
   repletion
   -Will work to wean sedation as possible as may be a contributor to
   hypotension
   -ECHO to f/u if quick response is not seen
   4)Atrial Fibrillation-
   -Paitent with A-fib suggested on ECG and telemetry
   -Will consider cardioversion if persistent hypotension seen and not
   able to be tolerated with pressor support
   -ECG changes may well be demand ischemia and will follow enzymes which
   are negative to date.
   -Will continue Digoxin as patient transiently in sinus rhythm
    5)Pneumonthorax-
   -Chest tube in place, maintain suction
   -Currently with small leak noted
   -Minimal drainage
   - continued chest tube while on postive pressure ventilation and until
   air appears to have drained from chest tube completely
   EKG changes:  Diffuse T wave inversions in inferior and anterior
   distribution.  Most likely related to demand ischemia in RCA and LAD
   territory.  Pulmonary embolism considered but would be less likely to
   cause strain in both arterial territories.  Diffuse changes also less
   consistent with myocardial infarction.
   - repeat EKG after improvement in hemodynamics
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - echocardiogram today
   .
   Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  Currently with dark black material
   in NGT which is hemoccult negative.  Per hospitalist on floor, this
   likely is related to bannana flakes in patient's tube feeds.  On floor
   patient continued to have severe nausea and vomiting in relation to any
   PO intake.  Gastric emptying study showed 0% emptying at 4 hours.  Also
   stool occult positive.
   - serial hematocrits given concern initially for GI bleeding
   - active type and cross
   - currently intubated, sedated
   - nutrition consult
   - currently with significant black material being suctioned from
   stomach so unlikely will be able to administer PO medications or tube
   feeds until this has improved
   - currently holding j-tube feeds
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   .
   Chronic Abdominal Pain:  Likely related to gastritis.  Also concern
   that G-J tube may have possible leak.  Being followed by GI consult
   service.  She has had many upper endoscopies and suboptimal
   colonoscopies.  Plans is currently for optomizing her nutritional
   status and ultimately rehab.
   - currently on fentanyl for sedation, will have to reassess pain
   regimen when sedation decreased
   - follow gastroenterology recommendations
   .
   Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Previously in this admission with mild iron
   deficiency and chronic disease.  Baseline hematocrit 30-35.  Currently
   26 in the setting of significant IV fluid administration.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   - active type and screen
   .
   COPD: Severe emphysema on imaging.  Likely contributing to her
   respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers of xopenex and ipratropium
   - titrate oxygen for sats > 90%
   .
   Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty.
   - continue fentanyl for sedation
   - reassess pain regimen once medications weaned
   .
   FEN: NPO, IVF for above parameters, nutrition consult, replete

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a complicated medical history, including esophagectomy, COPD, atrial arrhythmia, and chronic abdominal pain. She was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress, recurrent coffee ground emesis, and melena. She was intubated and placed on pressors due to hypotension. A pneumothorax was diagnosed and treated with a chest tube. The patient has significant changes in her ECG, including diffuse T-wave inversions, which may be related to demand ischemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to aspiration and mucus plugging, which is exacerbated by her severe background lung disease. She requires continued mechanical ventilation and may require further interventions to improve oxygenation.
2. Shock: The patient is at risk for shock due to her hypotension, which may be related to sepsis, hypovolemia, or cardiogenic shock. She requires continued pressor support and may require further interventions to improve cardiac output.
3. Pneumothorax: The patient's pneumothorax requires continued monitoring and treatment with a chest tube to prevent recurrence.
4. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's melena and hemoccult-negative stool suggest gastrointestinal bleeding, which may be related to gastritis, gastroesophageal reflux disease, or other causes. She requires continued monitoring and treatment with proton pump inhibitors and other medications as needed.
5. Chronic Abdominal Pain: The patient's chronic abdominal pain is likely related to gastritis and may require further evaluation and treatment with gastroenterology consultation.
6. Chronic Blood Loss Anemia: The patient's chronic blood loss anemia requires continued monitoring and treatment with iron supplements and other medications as needed.
7. COPD: The patient's severe COPD requires continued treatment with bronchodilators, oxygen therapy, and other medications as needed.
8. Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures: The patient's chronic back pain and compression fractures require continued treatment with pain management and other interventions as needed.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient requires continued ICU care and monitoring to manage her respiratory failure, shock, and other medical complications. She requires continued mechanical ventilation, pressor support, and other interventions as needed. She also requires further evaluation and treatment for her gastrointestinal bleeding, chronic abdominal pain, and chronic blood loss anemia.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 66-year-old woman with a history of COPD, esophagectomy, and malnutrition who was admitted 40 days ago for malnutrition. She had a sudden onset of respiratory distress, vomiting coffee-ground emesis, and was intubated emergently. She was admitted to the ICU and was found to have a pneumothorax, which was treated with a chest tube. She was started on pressors and sedation, and her EKG showed anterolateral T-wave inversions, which suggests possible CAD. She is currently receiving mechanical ventilation, and her vital signs are stable, but she remains critically ill.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Aspiration Pneumonia**: The patient's respiratory failure is suspected to be caused by aspiration, and she is receiving antibiotics for this condition. However, there is a risk of further aspiration and development of pneumonia.
2. **Pneumothorax**: The patient had a pneumothorax, which was treated with a chest tube. However, there is a risk of recurrence or development of a new pneumothorax.
3. **Cardiac Complications**: The patient's EKG shows anterolateral T-wave inversions, which suggests possible CAD. There is a risk of cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
4. **Sepsis**: The patient is receiving antibiotics for aspiration pneumonia, and there is a risk of sepsis developing.
5. **Gastrointestinal Complications**: The patient has a history of esophagectomy and is receiving sedation, which may lead to gastrointestinal complications such as constipation, nausea, or vomiting.
6. **Nutritional Complications**: The patient is malnourished and is receiving nutrition support. However, there is a risk of malnutrition-related complications, such as decreased immune function or wound healing complications.
7. **Pain Management**: The patient is receiving sedation and pain management, and there is a risk of oversedation or undertreatment of pain.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue antibiotics for aspiration pneumonia and monitor for signs of sepsis.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider further evaluation for CAD.
4. Continue to provide nutrition support and monitor for signs of malnutrition-related complications.
5. Monitor the patient's pain status and adjust pain management as needed.
6. Consider placing an arterial line to monitor the patient's blood pressure and hemodynamic status.

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old woman with a history of COPD, esophagectomy, and malnutrition, who was admitted 40 days ago for malnutrition. She developed respiratory distress, vomiting coffee ground emesis, and code blue, leading to emergent intubation. She was admitted to the ICU and has been receiving mechanical ventilation, pressors, and sedation. The patient has a pneumothorax, which was treated with a chest tube, and has been receiving antibiotics for aspiration pneumonia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to aspiration of food material into her lungs, which can lead to further respiratory distress and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Pneumothorax: The patient's pneumothorax can lead to respiratory compromise and potentially life-threatening complications if not properly treated.
3. Sepsis: The patient's aspiration pneumonia and respiratory failure increase her risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's EKG changes, including anterolateral Tw inversions, suggest that she may have coronary artery disease, which can lead to cardiovascular instability and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of esophagectomy and malnutrition increase her risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as aspiration, nausea, and vomiting, which can lead to further respiratory and cardiovascular instability.
6. Sedation and analgesia: The patient's use of sedation and analgesia increases her risk of respiratory and cardiovascular depression, which can lead to further complications and potentially life-threatening outcomes.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's history of malnutrition and ongoing nutritional deficiencies increase her risk of further complications, including respiratory and cardiovascular instability, and potentially life-threatening outcomes.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and pressors to manage the patient's respiratory failure and cardiovascular instability.
2. Continue antibiotics for aspiration pneumonia and consider adding additional antibiotics if the patient's condition worsens.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular status closely and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent further complications.
4. Consider placing an arterial line to monitor the patient's blood pressure and cardiovascular status.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and provide adequate nutrition to prevent further complications.
6. Consider adding additional medications, such as vasopressors, to manage the patient's cardiovascular instability.
7. Monitor the patient's sedation and analgesia levels closely and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent respiratory and cardiovascular depression.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old female with a complex medical history, including COPD, esophageal perforation, and gastroparesis, who was admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: Hypoxic respiratory failure, with an A-a gradient of 241, and a requirement for mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50%.
* Cardiovascular status: Patient has moderate pulmonary hypertension and an ejection fraction greater than 55%.
* Hemodynamic status: Patient has been treated with fluid boluses and has a central venous pressure (CVP) of 9 mmHg, which is being managed to maintain a goal CVP of 10-12 mmHg.
* Renal status: Patient has a creatinine level of 0.4 mg/dL, which is within normal limits.
* Coagulation status: Patient has a platelet count of 331 K/uL and an international normalized ratio (INR) of 1.1, which is within normal limits.
* Nutritional status: Patient is NPO and receiving IV fluids and nutrition through a J-tube.
* Infectious disease status: Patient has a suspected aspiration pneumonia, and cultures are pending.
* Pain management: Patient is receiving fentanyl for sedation and has a pain regimen in place.
* Electrolyte management: Patient is receiving calcium and vitamin D supplementation.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: Patient's hypoxic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further decline in oxygenation and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Cardiac complications: Patient's moderate pulmonary hypertension and ejection fraction greater than 55% may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
3. Bleeding complications: Patient's thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy may increase the risk of bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage.
4. Infection: Patient's suspected aspiration pneumonia may worsen, leading to sepsis or multi-organ dysfunction.
5. Malnutrition: Patient's gastroparesis and inability to tolerate oral nutrition may lead to malnutrition and further compromise her immune function.
6. Electrolyte imbalances: Patient's IV fluids and nutrition may lead to electrolyte imbalances, such as hyperkalemia or hypocalcemia.
7. Pain management: Patient's pain regimen may not be adequately managed, leading to discomfort and potentially worsening respiratory status.

Based on the patient's current condition, it is recommended that she continue to receive close monitoring and management in the ICU, with a focus on optimizing her respiratory status, managing her pain and electrolyte imbalances, and preventing complications such as bleeding or infection.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment/Plan: 66 year old female with COPD on 2L oxygen, esophageal
   perforation s/p esophagectomy and severe gastroparesis transferred to
   the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] for acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.
   Acute Respiratory Failure:  Both hypercarbic and hypoxic.  Patient
   initially suctioned with retrieval of large mucous plug but
   subsequently started vomiting with inability to protect airway
   requiring emergent intubation.  Suspect respiratory failure is
   multifactorial relating to patient's underlying severe emphysema,
   mucous plugging and possible pneumonia.  Pulmonary embolism and cardiac
   ischemic also considered given respiratory failure and hypotension
   although would expect CVP to be elevated in these settings and clinical
   picture more consistent with other etiologies.
   - start vancomycin and zosyn for hospital acquired pneumonia
   - xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers
   - deep suctioning if possible
   - will send sputum sample
   - blood and urine culures pending
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   Shock:  Patient became acutely hypotensive upon arrival to the MICU.
   Occurred in the setting of initiating sedating medications and
   intubation.  Also occurred in the setting of mucous plugging, rising
   white blood cell count and concern for aspiration.  CVP is low which
   would be consistent with either hypovolemic shock, decreased preload
   from medications and effects of positive pressure ventilation, and
   septic shock.  Cardiac and obstructive etiologies also considered given
   EKG changes but for now clinical picture appears more consistent
   infection vs. decreased preload.
   - IVF fluid boluses to maintain CVP 10-12, urine output 30cc/hr and SBP
   > 90
   - Levophed to maintain above paremeters
   - Repeat EKG
   - Rule out for myocardial infarction with serial cardiac enzymes
   - Vancomycin and Zosyn to cover for hospital acquired pneumonia
   - Repeat CXR in AM to assess size of pneumothorax
   - Attempt to limit use of midazolam since patient's blood pressures
   seem particularly sensitive to this [**Doctor Last Name **]
   - echocardiogram in AM
   Tension Pneumothorax:  Now s/p decompression and chest tube placement
   with good re-expansion on CXR.  Air leak present.
   - chest tube to suction
   - serial CXR
   Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia: Currently her rate is in the 100s.
   - continue digoxin
   - holding metoprolol given hypotension
   EKG changes:  Diffuse T wave inversions in inferior and anterior
   distribution.  Most likely related to demand ischemia in RCA and LAD
   territory.  Pulmonary embolism considered but would be less likely to
   cause strain in both arterial territories.  Diffuse changes also less
   consistent with myocardial infarction.
   - repeat EKG after improvement in hemodynamics
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - echocardiogram in AM
   Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  Currently with dark black material
   in NGT which is hemoccult negative.  Per hospitalist on floor, this
   likely is related to bannana flakes in patient's tube feeds.  On floor
   patient continued to have severe nausea and vomiting in relation to any
   PO intake.  Gastric emptying study showed 0% emptying at 4 hours.
   - serial hematocrits given concern initially for GI bleeding
   - active type and cross
   - currently intubated, sedated
   - nutrition consult in AM
   - currently with significant black material being suctioned from
   stomach so unlikely will be able to administer PO medications or tube
   feeds until this has improved
   - currently holding j-tube feeds
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   Chronic Abdominal Pain:  Likely related to gastritis.  Also concern
   that G-J tube may have possible leak.  Being followed by GI consult
   service.  She has had many upper endoscopies and suboptimal
   colonoscopies.  Plans is currently for optomizing her nutritional
   status and ultimately rehab.
   - currently on fentanyl for sedation, will have to reassess pain
   regimen when sedation decreased
   - follow gastroenterology recommendations
   Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Previously in this admission with mild iron
   deficiency and chronic disease.  Baseline hematocrit 30-35.  Currently
   26 in the setting of significant IV fluid administration.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   - active type and screen
   COPD: Severe emphysema on imaging.  Likely contributing to her
   respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers
   - titrate oxygen for sats > 90%
   Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty.
   - continue fentanyl for sedation
   - reassess pain regimen once medications weaned
   FEN: NPO, IVF for above parameters, nutrition consult, replete
   electrolytes

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old female with a complex medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), esophageal perforation, and severe gastroparesis. She was transferred to the ICU for acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.

The patient's current condition is multifactorial, with acute respiratory failure, shock, and tension pneumothorax. She has a history of chronic abdominal pain, chronic blood loss anemia, and compression fractures. She is currently intubated and sedated, with a Swan-Ganz catheter in place to monitor her hemodynamics.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of respiratory failure, including hypercarbic and hypoxic respiratory failure. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) results indicate a pH of 7.44, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) of 42 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) of 63 mmHg.

The patient's chest X-ray (CXR) shows a large pneumothorax, which was decompressed and treated with a chest tube. Her electrocardiogram (EKG) shows diffuse T-wave inversions in the inferior and anterior distribution, which may be related to demand ischemia or cardiac ischemia.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Treatment of acute respiratory failure with oxygen therapy, mechanical ventilation, and bronchodilators.
2. Management of shock with fluid resuscitation, vasopressor therapy, and monitoring of hemodynamics.
3. Treatment of tension pneumothorax with chest tube placement and suction.
4. Management of gastroparesis with nasogastric suction and consideration of gastric emptying study.
5. Treatment of chronic abdominal pain with pain management and consideration of gastroenterology consultation.
6. Management of chronic blood loss anemia with transfusion therapy and consideration of iron supplementation.
7. Treatment of COPD with bronchodilators and oxygen therapy.
8. Management of chronic back pain with pain management and consideration of orthopedic consultation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may progress to chronic respiratory failure, leading to long-term disability and mortality.
2. Shock: The patient's shock may worsen, leading to multi-organ failure and mortality.
3. Pneumothorax: The patient's tension pneumothorax may recur, leading to respiratory failure and mortality.
4. Gastroparesis: The patient's gastroparesis may worsen, leading to malnutrition, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance.
5. Chronic abdominal pain: The patient's chronic abdominal pain may worsen, leading to decreased quality of life and increased risk of complications.
6. Chronic blood loss anemia: The patient's chronic blood loss anemia may worsen, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues and increased risk of organ failure.
7. COPD: The patient's COPD may worsen, leading to increased risk of respiratory failure and mortality.
8. Chronic back pain: The patient's chronic back pain may worsen, leading to decreased mobility, decreased quality of life, and increased risk of complications.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions requiring multidisciplinary care. The patient's condition is unstable, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU with respiratory failure. The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4C, heart rate of 95 bpm, blood pressure of 119/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 126.

The patient has a history of sepsis, with a preliminary diagnosis of E. coli infection. The patient has received antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam. The patient's laboratory results show evidence of organ dysfunction, including elevated lactate levels and decreased albumin levels.

The patient's physical examination reveals signs of respiratory distress, including wheezing and bronchospasm. The patient's extremities are swollen, with a right hand that is extremely swollen. The patient's neurologic examination shows decreased level of consciousness, with no spontaneous movement or response to noxious stimuli.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 126. The patient may be at risk for further respiratory deterioration, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis, with a preliminary diagnosis of E. coli infection. The patient may be at risk for further sepsis-related complications, including organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Organ dysfunction: The patient's laboratory results show evidence of organ dysfunction, including elevated lactate levels and decreased albumin levels. The patient may be at risk for further organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury (AKI) and acute liver injury (ALI).
4. Neurologic complications: The patient's neurologic examination shows decreased level of consciousness, with no spontaneous movement or response to noxious stimuli. The patient may be at risk for further neurologic complications, including stroke and seizures.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiovascular status is concerning, with a blood pressure of 119/64 mmHg and a heart rate of 95 bpm. The patient may be at risk for further cardiovascular complications, including cardiogenic shock and arrhythmias.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's gastrointestinal status is concerning, with a guaiac-positive stool and a preliminary diagnosis of E. coli infection. The patient may be at risk for further gastrointestinal complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 yo female admit with respiratory failure and likley aspiration event
   and mucus plugging in the setting of a history of esophagectomy and
   initial emergent placement of SCV catheter was complicated by
   pneumothorax.  She has had some improvement in hemodynamics but remains
   with pressor requirement.
   1)Respiratory Failure-
   -Primary hypoxemia persists.  She has reasonable control of her
   ventialtion with adequate Ve maintained
   -Pneumothorax has resolved and air leak is not seen
   -Source is multi-factorial for persistent hypoxemic respiratory failure
   -[**Month (only) 8**] be contribution from left sided collapse
will maintain adequate
   PEEP
   -[**Month (only) 8**] be underlying pulmonary disease with significant emphysema and
   ineffective V/Q with significant apical dead space.
   -[**Month (only) 8**] be PE as has been raised but there is alternative explanations
   offered
given persistent hypoxemia will have to re-consider diagnosis
   if no clinical improvement seen.  Will check LENI at this time.
   2)COPD with acute exacerbation-
   -Continue with bronchodilators
   -Continue with ABX for pulmonary infection and sepsis
   3)Sepsis-Likely from pulmonary source
   -Continue antibiotics
   -Wean pressors
   -Keep CVP=12 as goal
   4)Pneumothorax-
   -Move to water seal today
   -Repeat CXR to evaluate PTX
   -Will continue to discuss with surgery as to timing of removal but
   would favor maintenance while PPV is in place
   5)Atrial Tachycardia-
   -Lopressor held
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old female admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, likely due to aspiration and mucus plugging, in the setting of a history of esophagectomy and initial emergent placement of SCV catheter complicated by pneumothorax. She has had some improvement in hemodynamics but remains on pressors. The patient has a multi-factorial respiratory failure, including primary hypoxemia, pneumothorax, underlying pulmonary disease with significant emphysema, and potential PE. She is also diagnosed with COPD with acute exacerbation, sepsis likely from a pulmonary source, and atrial tachycardia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's primary hypoxemia persists, and there is a risk of further deterioration if not managed adequately.
2. Pneumothorax: The patient has a risk of recurrent pneumothorax, particularly if the water seal is not effective or if the patient is not closely monitored.
3. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen if not managed appropriately, leading to organ dysfunction and potential mortality.
4. Atrial tachycardia: The patient's atrial tachycardia may lead to cardiac arrhythmias and potentially life-threatening complications if not managed properly.
5. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of PE and potential underlying pulmonary disease increase the risk of recurrent PE, which could lead to further respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Infection: The patient's sepsis and pulmonary infection may lead to further complications, such as septic shock, organ dysfunction, and potential mortality.
7. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of esophagectomy and potential underlying cardiac disease increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiac failure, and potentially life-threatening events.
8. Nutritional complications: The patient's tube feeds and glycemic control may lead to nutritional deficiencies and potential complications, such as hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
9. Line-related complications: The patient's multiple lines, including the arterial line, PICC line, and multi-lumen line, may increase the risk of line-related complications, such as infection, bleeding, or thrombosis.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of mucus plugging and aspiration. The patient's respiratory support is currently being managed with mechanical ventilation, but there is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
2. Pneumothorax: The patient has a history of pneumothorax on the right side, which has been decompressed and treated with a chest tube. There is a risk of recurrence or development of a new pneumothorax.
3. Shock: The patient's hypotension is likely due to sepsis, sedation, and possibly transient bacteremia. The patient's CVP is improving with fluid boluses, but there is a risk of further deterioration if the patient's fluid status is not closely monitored.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of gastroparesis, nausea, and vomiting, which may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's NG tube is currently being suctioned, which may reduce the risk of bleeding.
5. Chronic blood loss anemia: The patient has a history of mild iron deficiency and chronic disease, which may worsen if the patient's anemia is not managed properly.
6. Infection: The patient's sputum culture grew gram-negative rods and budding yeast, which may indicate a pulmonary infection. The patient's antibiotic regimen should be adjusted based on the culture results.
7. Fluid overload: The patient has received a significant amount of IV fluid, which may lead to fluid overload and increased risk of complications.
8. Malnutrition: The patient's gastroparesis and nausea may lead to malnutrition, which may worsen the patient's overall condition.

To mitigate these risks, the patient's care team should:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
2. Closely monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust fluid administration accordingly.
3. Manage the patient's gastroparesis and nausea with anti-nausea medications and consider tube feeds.
4. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust fluid and medication administration accordingly.
5. Consider adjusting the patient's antibiotic regimen based on the culture results.
6. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust medication administration accordingly.
7. Consider referring the patient to a nutritionist for further evaluation and management of malnutrition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old female with a complicated medical history, including esophagectomy, complicated GI history, and chronic respiratory failure. The patient was transferred to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, likely due to a combination of mucus plugging and aspiration.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.2C (98.9F)
* Heart rate: 99 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 90/54 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 97%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 350 mL and a respiratory rate of 20 bpm. The patient is also receiving oxygen therapy with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Shock: The patient has hypotension and is receiving fluid boluses to improve cardiac output.
2. Tension pneumothorax: The patient had a pneumothorax in the right side after subclavian line placement, which was decompressed and treated with a chest tube.
3. Multifocal atrial tachycardia: The patient's heart rate is in the 100s, and digoxin is being continued to manage the arrhythmia.
4. Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition: The patient has severe gastroparesis and is unable to tolerate oral feeds. The patient is also experiencing nausea and vomiting.
5. Chronic blood loss anemia: The patient has a history of mild iron deficiency and chronic disease, and is currently anemic due to significant IV fluid administration.
6. COPD: The patient has severe emphysema, which is contributing to her respiratory failure.
7. Chronic back pain/compression fractures: The patient has multiple thoracic compression fractures, which are causing chronic back pain.

The patient is currently receiving the following medications:

* Fentanyl for sedation
* Midazolam for sedation
* Vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for infection
* Digoxin for atrial tachycardia
* Calcium and vitamin D supplements
* Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) for gastroparesis
* Heparin for prophylaxis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)

The patient's laboratory results are:

* White blood cell count: 17.5-18.4 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.3-9.2 g/dL
* Platelet count: 314-349 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.3-0.4 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.05-0.05 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.6 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.0 g/dL
* LDH: 208 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.2 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.5 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.7 mg/dL

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for infection
* Repeating chest X-ray (CXR) in the morning
* Continuing fluid boluses to improve cardiac output
* Reassessing pain regimen once medications are weaned
* Continuing nutrition consult and repleting electrolytes
* Continuing prophylaxis with heparin for DVT
* Full code status

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old female admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and hypotension. She has a history of esophagectomy and emergent placement of a subclavian central venous catheter, which was complicated by pneumothorax. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a Gent-sensitive E. coli infection with borderline sensitivity to pip/taz, and a 3+ GNR sputum culture. She is febrile and has a history of severe malnutrition.

Key findings:

* The patient has severe respiratory failure attributed to severe emphysema, worsened V/Q mismatch, and dense consolidation from aspiration pneumonia.
* She has a pneumothorax that was resolved with a chest tube, and a new central line will be placed today.
* The patient is septic, with evidence of pulmonary and urinary tract infections.
* She has a J-tube for nutrition, but is not receiving goal nutrition, and may require total parenteral nutrition (TPN) in the future.
* The patient has multiple lines, including a multi-lumen line, PICC line, and arterial line.
* She is receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential medical complications:

* Further decline in respiratory function due to ongoing sepsis and pneumonia
* Development of ventilator-associated complications, such as ventilator-induced lung injury
* Increased risk of bleeding due to sepsis and coagulopathy
* Potential for cardiac arrest due to septic shock
* Increased risk of nosocomial infections due to prolonged ICU stay and multiple lines
* Malnutrition and related complications, such as weakness, fatigue, and impaired wound healing
* Potential for further complications related to the patient's esophagectomy, such as esophageal perforation or stricture.

Summary:

The patient, a 66-year-old female, is critically ill and intubated in the ICU due to respiratory failure and hypotension. She was admitted with a likely aspiration event and mucus plugging in the setting of a history of esophagectomy and initial emergent placement of a subclavian central venous catheter, which was complicated by pneumothorax. She has septic shock due to pulmonary and urinary tract infections, and has been treated with antibiotics. The patient has severe emphysema and worsened V/Q mismatch with dense consolidation from aspiration pneumonia, which is contributing to her severe respiratory failure. She also has severe malnutrition and is not receiving goal nutrition through her J-tube, with consideration for total parenteral nutrition (TPN) after reviewing her tube feed history.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Progressive respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, and if not managed appropriately, may lead to further decline in lung function, potentially requiring mechanical ventilation or even death.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt and aggressive management to prevent organ dysfunction and death.
3. Pneumothorax: The patient's history of pneumothorax and the presence of a central line increase her risk of recurrent pneumothorax, which could lead to respiratory compromise and even death.
4. Malnutrition: The patient's severe malnutrition increases her risk of complications, including poor wound healing, infections, and prolonged recovery.
5. VAP: The patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation increase her risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which can lead to sepsis, respiratory failure, and even death.
6. DVT: The patient's immobility and central lines increase her risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can lead to pulmonary embolism and death if not managed promptly.
7. Stress ulcer: The patient's critical illness and use of antibiotics increase her risk of stress ulcer, which can lead to gastrointestinal bleeding and potentially life-threatening complications.
8. Organ dysfunction: The patient's septic shock and respiratory failure increase her risk of organ dysfunction, including renal, hepatic, and cardiovascular dysfunction, which can lead to multi-organ failure and death.

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of COPD, esophageal perforation, and gastroparesis, who was transferred to the ICU for acute respiratory failure requiring intubation. She has a small, stable right-sided pleural effusion and is being treated for aspiration pneumonia, urosepsis, and tension pneumothorax. She is also experiencing gastroparesis, nausea, and malnutrition.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.6C (101.4F), heart rate of 86 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 121/62 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 100% on a FiO2 of 50%. She has a CVP of 26.3 mmHg and a platelet count of 333 K/uL.

The patient's laboratory results show a WBC count of 17.5 K/uL, Hct of 26.2%, and a creatinine level of 0.4 mg/dL. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly low potassium level of 3.8 mEq/L. Her troponin-T level is 0.05 ng/mL, and her lactic acid level is 0.6 mmol/L.

The patient's current medications include vancomycin, zosyn, gentamycin, and fentanyl, and she is receiving IV fluids and oxygen therapy. She is also receiving enteral nutrition and has a nasogastric tube in place.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to her underlying COPD and aspiration pneumonia. She may require further respiratory support, such as non-invasive ventilation or mechanical ventilation.
2. Urosepsis: The patient's urosepsis is likely due to her urinary tract infection, and she may require further antibiotic treatment and fluid resuscitation.
3. Tension pneumothorax: The patient's tension pneumothorax has been decompressed, but she may require further monitoring and treatment to prevent recurrence.
4. Gastroparesis: The patient's gastroparesis is likely contributing to her malnutrition and may require further treatment, such as nutritional supplements or total parenteral nutrition (TPN).
5. Chronic blood loss anemia: The patient's chronic blood loss anemia is likely due to her underlying medical conditions and may require further treatment, such as blood transfusions or iron supplements.
6. Chronic back pain and compression fractures: The patient's chronic back pain and compression fractures may require further management, such as pain medication or physical therapy.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition is likely due to her gastroparesis and may require further treatment, such as nutritional supplements or TPN.
8. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance, particularly her low potassium level, may require further treatment, such as potassium supplements or IV fluids.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old female with a complex medical history, including COPD, esophageal perforation, and severe gastroparesis. She was admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is mechanically ventilated with a CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow mode, with a tidal volume of 350 mL and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation is 100% on 50% FiO2. The patient has a small, stable right-sided pneumothorax (PTX) subclavian line placement.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has hypotension, with a blood pressure of 121/62 mmHg. Her central venous pressure (CVP) is 26.3 mmHg, which is improving with boluses. Her echocardiogram shows an ejection fraction (EF) >55% and moderate pulmonary hypertension.
* Hematological: The patient has a chronic blood loss anemia, with a baseline hematocrit of 30-35. Her current hematocrit is 26, which is likely due to significant IV fluid administration.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has severe gastroparesis, with a gastric emptying study showing 0% emptying at 4 hours. She is currently intubated and sedated, with significant black material being suctioned from her stomach.
* Infectious: The patient has a sputum culture positive for GNR and 2+ budding yeast, suggestive of aspiration pneumonia. She is receiving coverage with gentamycin, zosyn, and vancomycin.
* Other: The patient has a history of chronic back pain and compression fractures, and is receiving prophylaxis with SC heparin and PPI.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Pneumonia: The patient's sputum culture is positive for GNR and 2+ budding yeast, which may indicate a worsening of her pneumonia.
* Septic shock: The patient's hypotension and tachycardia may be indicative of septic shock, particularly given her history of pneumonia and gastroparesis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is precarious, and she may require further interventions to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastroparesis and recent bleeding from her NG tube may increase her risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Blood loss anemia: The patient's chronic blood loss anemia may worsen with continued bleeding or blood transfusions.
* Pneumothorax: The patient's small, stable right-sided PTX may expand or worsen with continued respiratory failure or bleeding.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current status, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of her respiratory, cardiovascular, and gastrointestinal systems. Further interventions may be necessary to prevent or manage potential complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old female with a complex medical history, including COPD, esophageal perforation, and severe gastroparesis. She is currently in the ICU due to acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

* Hypoxic respiratory failure: Exacerbated by aspiration pneumonia and likely mucus plugging.
* Shock: Likely caused by urosepsis and PNA, with a CVP of 26.3 mmHg.
* Tension pneumothorax: Decompressed and treated with a chest tube.
* Multifocal atrial tachycardia: Currently being treated with digoxin.
* Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition: Questionable GI function, with minimal residual TF and possible bowel edema.
* Chronic blood loss anemia: Previously diagnosed with mild iron deficiency and chronic disease.
* COPD: Severe emphysema at baseline.
* Chronic back pain/compression fractures: Multiple thoracic compression fractures.

The patient's medications include:

* Gentamycin for E. coli and Enterococcus in urine
* Zosyn for aspiration coverage
* Vancomycin for aspiration coverage
* Midazolam for sedation
* Fentanyl for sedation and pain management
* Heparin for prophylaxis
* Piperacillin for prophylaxis
* TPN for nutrition
* Tylenol for GI function assessment

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Worsening of respiratory failure due to inadequate ventilation or oxygenation.
* Progression of shock or urosepsis, potentially leading to organ dysfunction or failure.
* Recurrence of tension pneumothorax or development of a new one.
* Complications related to gastroparesis, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
* Development of gastrointestinal bleeding due to chronic blood loss anemia.
* Increased risk of infection due to prolonged ICU stay and use of invasive devices.
* Potential for medication interactions or side effects, particularly with the use of multiple antibiotics and sedatives.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current conditions, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management to prevent or mitigate potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a fever of 101.4F (38.6C) and a history of sepsis. They have been receiving antibiotics for E. coli and Enterococcus in their urine. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 350 mL and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. They have a central venous catheter and an arterial line in place. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate dehydrogenase, and creatinine levels. Their platelet count is 333 K/uL, and their hemoglobin level is 7.4 g/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's elevated lactate dehydrogenase and creatinine levels suggest potential sepsis-related organ dysfunction.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's requirement for mechanical ventilation and their elevated respiratory system resistance (RSBI) indicate potential respiratory failure.
3. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's elevated heart rate and blood pressure suggest potential cardiovascular instability.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's elevated lactate dehydrogenase level and potential stress ulcer prophylaxis suggest potential gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Venous thromboembolism: The patient's central venous catheter and prophylactic anticoagulation therapy suggest potential venous thromboembolism.
6. Infection: The patient's positive sputum culture for GNR and their elevated white blood cell count suggest potential infection.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's elevated potassium and magnesium levels suggest potential electrolyte imbalance.
8. Renal dysfunction: The patient's elevated creatinine level and potential kidney damage from sepsis suggest potential renal dysfunction.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for E. coli and Enterococcus in the urine.
2. Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely for signs of sepsis-related organ dysfunction.
3. Consider adjusting the patient's mechanical ventilation settings to improve their respiratory status.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely for signs of instability.
5. Consider prophylactic anticoagulation therapy for venous thromboembolism.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status closely for signs of bleeding.
7. Consider adjusting the patient's electrolyte levels to prevent imbalance.
8. Monitor the patient's renal function closely for signs of dysfunction.

* Temperature: 38.6C (101.4F) at 10:00 AM, and 37.1C (98.8F) currently
* Heart rate: 86 beats per minute (bpm) with a normal range of 85-125 bpm
* Blood pressure: 121/62 mmHg with a normal range of 78-123/42-85 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 inspirations per minute (insp/min) with a normal range of 19-32 insp/min
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with the following settings:

* Ventilator mode: CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow
* Tidal volume (Vt): 350 mL
* Respiratory rate (RR): 20
* Positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP): 5 cmH2O
* Fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2): 50%

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Rhonchus on inspiration with expiratory wheezes throughout
* R arm edematous, L arm cool compared to R (side of A-line)
* B/l lower extremities cool
* 1+dp pulses

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 17.5-12.1 K/uL
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 7.4 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 333 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 0.4-0.4 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.05 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.6 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.0 g/dL
* LDH: 208 IU/L
* Calcium (Ca++): 6.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium (Mg++): 1.7 mg/dL
* Phosphorus (PO4): 2.9 mg/dL

The patient's medical history includes allergies to codeine and hives, and a history of E. coli and Enterococcus in the urine. The patient is receiving antibiotics, including gentamycin, piperacillin/tazobactam, and vancomycin.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

* Sepsis and septic shock due to the presence of E. coli and Enterococcus in the urine
* Respiratory failure due to the patient's underlying lung disease and the need for mechanical ventilation
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to the patient's tachycardia and potential electrolyte imbalances
* Renal failure due to the patient's elevated creatinine levels
* Hepatic dysfunction due to the patient's elevated liver enzymes
* Nutritional deficiencies due to the patient's inability to eat and the need for enteral nutrition
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) due to the patient's immobility and potential hypercoagulability

It is essential to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition closely to identify any potential complications and adjust treatment accordingly.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old female with COPD on 2L oxygen, esophageal perforation s/p
   esophagectomy and severe gastroparesis transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] for
   acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Known COPD and emphysema exacerbated by
   aspiration pneumonia. Inititally question of mucus plugging as well.
   She currently has a small, stable R sided PTX [**3-3**] subclavian line
   placement.  Sputum with 3+GNR and 2+ budding yeast suggestive of
   aspiration PNA, and likely covered by zosyn and vancomycin.  Patient
   now on pressure support [**11-4**] with FiO2 of 50%. She is moving ~350cc and
   RR 15 with those settings. Patient almost at baseline mental status,
   diminished gag reflex, normal secretions, but got very agitated,
   tachycardic, hypertensive and desated when tried to be weaned. Now on
   Haldol standing plus zyprexa PRN.
   - Continue vancomycin/Zosyn  for aspiration coverage (day 2 and 5
   respectively)
   - F/u culture data
   - attempt to wean sedation and decrease FiO2; may be candidate for
   extubation later today.
   - Keep chest tube for today, since there is still PTX on CXR
   # Agitation: Patient became agitated when tried to be weaned of vent.
   -          Continue haldol PRN
   -          Continue Quetitapine PRN
   # Shock: Patient in shock likely [**3-3**] urosepsis & PNA all involving GRN
   for which she is receiving zosyn. Echocardiogram with EF >55% and
   moderate pulmonary hypertension.
   - continue fluid boluses; goal CVP 10-12
   - speciate GNR in sputum and adjust coverage as needed
   - vanco/zosyn (day 2 and 5 respectively)
   # Tension Pneumothorax:  Now s/p decompression and chest tube placement
   with good re-expansion on CXR.  Air leak noted today while pt on water
   seal yesterday. Put back on low suction, will follow final read of CXR
   and if no pneumo will try again to put on water seal.
   - chest tube to low suction
   - check CXR this PM
   - f/u thoracic recs
   # Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia: Currently her rate is in the 80s.
   - continue digoxin
   - can restart metoprolol today
   # Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  There is question whether or not
   patient is absorbing her TF. Residuals have been minimal which is
   promising however it is possible she has bowel edema that prevents her
   from absorbing nutrients, causing her malnutrition. Patient absorbed
   tylenol, so there is some degree of absorption. Will continue TF for
   now.
   - f/u nutrition recs
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   # Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Previously in this admission with mild
   iron deficiency and chronic disease.  Baseline hematocrit 30-35.
   Currently 23 in the setting of significant IV fluid administration,
   however her hct has trended down since admission. Has been guaiac + but
   this has been her baseline and there is question whether this is caused
   by irritation at the J-tube site. Will transfuse as needed for now if
   needed; she is hemodynamically stable.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   - active type and screen
   # COPD: Severe emphysema at baseline which is significant contributor
   of her respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers standing
   - titrate oxygen for sats >88-94%
   # Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty.
   - continue fentanyl for sedation
   - reassess pain regimen once medications weaned
   # FEN: TF for now, IVF for above parameters, replete electrolytes
   # Prophylaxis: SC  heparin, [**Hospital1 **], PPI
   # Code: Full code
   # Communication: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 849**] Daughter [**Known firstname 341**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 850**].  Alternate is
   son [**Telephone/Fax (1) 851**].
   # Lines : RIJ, PIV
   # Disposition: ICU care for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of COPD, esophageal perforation, and severe gastroparesis who was transferred to the ICU for acute respiratory failure. She is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a pressure support of 10 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%. Her current vital signs are within normal limits, but she is experiencing agitation and hypertension when sedation is decreased. She has a small, stable right-sided pneumothorax and is receiving vancomycin and Zosyn for aspiration coverage. Her labs show anemia, elevated white blood cell count, and mild liver enzyme elevation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's COPD and aspiration pneumonia put her at risk for continued respiratory failure, which could lead to further intubation and mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and possible urosepsis/PNA may lead to sepsis, which could worsen her respiratory and cardiovascular status.
3. Tension Pneumothorax: The patient's small, stable right-sided pneumothorax could worsen and become a tension pneumothorax, which could lead to cardiovascular compromise.
4. Shock: The patient's possible urosepsis/PNA and GRN coverage may lead to shock, which could worsen her respiratory and cardiovascular status.
5. Agitation: The patient's agitation and hypertension when sedation is decreased may lead to further complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or respiratory failure.
6. Malnutrition: The patient's gastroparesis and possible bowel edema may lead to malnutrition, which could worsen her overall health and increase the risk of complications.
7. Chronic Blood Loss Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if she continues to lose blood, which could lead to further cardiovascular compromise.
8. Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia: The patient's current rate in the 80s may worsen and lead to further cardiovascular complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's aspiration coverage with vancomycin and Zosyn, and monitor for signs of sepsis.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's pneumothorax and adjust suction settings as needed.
4. Continue to treat the patient's possible urosepsis/PNA with antibiotics and fluids, and monitor for signs of shock.
5. Continue to manage the patient's agitation with sedation and PRN medications.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's nutrition and consider enteral or parenteral nutrition if necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusion if necessary.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's multifocal atrial tachycardia and adjust medications as needed.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old female with COPD on 2L oxygen, esophageal perforation s/p
   esophagectomy and severe gastroparesis transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] for
   acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Known COPD and emphysema exacerbated by
   aspiration pneumonia. Inititally question of mucus plugging as well.
   She currently has a small, stable R sided PTX [**3-3**] subclavian line
   placement.  Sputum with 3+GNR and 2+ budding yeast suggestive of
   aspiration PNA, and likely covered by zosyn and vancomycin.  Patient
   now on pressure support [**11-4**] with FiO2 of 50%. She is moving ~350cc and
   RR 15 with those settings. Patient almost at baseline mental status,
   diminished gag reflex, normal secretions, but got very agitated,
   tachycardic, hypertensive and desated when tried to be weaned. Now on
   Haldol standing plus zyprexa PRN.
   - Continue vancomycin/Zosyn  for aspiration coverage (day 2 and 5
   respectively)
   - F/u culture data
   - attempt to wean sedation and decrease FiO2; may be candidate for
   extubation later today.
   - Keep chest tube for today, since there is still PTX on CXR
   # Agitation: Patient became agitated when tried to be weaned of vent.
   -          Continue haldol PRN
   -          Continue Quetitapine PRN
   # Shock: Patient in shock likely [**3-3**] urosepsis & PNA all involving GRN
   for which she is receiving zosyn. Echocardiogram with EF >55% and
   moderate pulmonary hypertension.
   - continue fluid boluses; goal CVP 10-12
   - speciate GNR in sputum and adjust coverage as needed
   - vanco/zosyn (day 2 and 5 respectively)
   # Tension Pneumothorax:  Now s/p decompression and chest tube placement
   with good re-expansion on CXR.  Air leak noted today while pt on water
   seal yesterday. Put back on low suction, will follow final read of CXR
   and if no pneumo will try again to put on water seal.
   - chest tube to low suction
   - check CXR this PM
   - f/u thoracic recs
   # Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia: Currently her rate is in the 80s.
   - continue digoxin
   - can restart metoprolol today
   # Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  There is question whether or not
   patient is absorbing her TF. Residuals have been minimal which is
   promising however it is possible she has bowel edema that prevents her
   from absorbing nutrients, causing her malnutrition. Patient absorbed
   tylenol, so there is some degree of absorption. Will continue TF for
   now.
   - f/u nutrition recs
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   # Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Previously in this admission with mild
   iron deficiency and chronic disease.  Baseline hematocrit 30-35.
   Currently 23 in the setting of significant IV fluid administration,
   however her hct has trended down since admission. Has been guaiac + but
   this has been her baseline and there is question whether this is caused
   by irritation at the J-tube site. Will transfuse as needed for now if
   needed; she is hemodynamically stable.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   - active type and screen
   # COPD: Severe emphysema at baseline which is significant contributor
   of her respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers standing
